awd_titl_txt: CHS: SHF: SMALL: Collaborative Research: Scaffolding skill acquisition to onboard OSS ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
This research aims to develop broadly applicable principles and methods to scaffold the newcomers' skill acquisition as they onboard into an Open Source Software (OSS) project, which in recent years has become an integral part of software development.  Although the long-term sustainability of OSS projects depends on the availability of a diverse, passionate group of volunteers, it is quite difficult to become a successful OSS developer. During the onboarding period, newcomers face several barriers such as: steep learning curve, setup misconfiguration, reception problems, and expectation breakdowns. These barriers result in many newcomers giving up, meaning the field may be losing many potential software developers.  This research will lead to new insights that can radically improve how newcomers onboard to software projects and to open source communities, which can broaden participation and increase retention. This project's empirical studies and infrastructure design pay particular attention to the fact that differences exist in how people problem-solve and use software features, and that these often cluster by gender. Therefore, broadening participation requires that tools and processes support different problem-solving styles, such that one group is not disproportionately impacted.

For this project, skills are defined as the capability of performing an activity; skills can refer to knowledge about the contribution process, programming concepts, or about a class of data, an application programming interface, a library, or the domain. The project objectives are: (1) create a model of skills that pertains to how to be successful in OSS, (2) design and evaluate approaches to extract these skills from open tasks in OSS projects, (3) scaffold skill acquisition of newcomers by matching developers' skills (and their goals) to available tasks in an OSS ecosystem, (4) investigate strategies and design solutions that promote gender inclusiveness, and (5) assess the approach through the design and evaluation of an infrastructure built in this research and made available to the OSS community.  The intellectual merit of the work is threefold. First, it will generate a deep understanding of skill models for software development tasks that is anchored and carefully validated in the context of tasks in an OSS ecosystem. Second, the researchers will design approaches that scaffold skill acquisition of developers to create a development trajectory that matches their current skill levels as well as their goals. Finally, a novel infrastructure will be designed and shared, that scaffolds the skill acquisition of newcomers, thereby, mitigating the effects of onboarding barriers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Open Source Software (OSS) has a significant impact on society in not only the software it produces, but also in the career paths it facilitates. The sustainability of many OSS projects is dependent on their ability to recruit and retain a diverse, motivated base of newcomers. The path to becoming a contributor, however, is not easy. Newcomers face several barriers when onboarding and only a small percentage of newcomers actually succeed, which is not only a loss for the projects but also a lost opportunity for developing the technology workforce. Moreover, OSS projects have very low gender diversity. This low gender diversity means that not only are OSS projects not leveraging a large section of the population and that potential women contributors are missing the learning opportunity, but also that the software produced itself is not gender inclusive.


In this project, we investigated the challenge of finding an appropriate task to work with, which is one of the most recurrent barriers that eventually prompt OSS newcomers to drop out. Newcomers are expected to be able to find a task that they can complete from a plethora of open issues that require different skills and are of varying complexity. The skills that are required for a task are difficult to infer solely from the task description, and very few projects annotate tasks to signal those that are appropriate for newcomers. More specifically, in this project, we (i) created a model of the skills needed to contribute to OSS projects; (ii) created an approach to identify the skills needed to complete an (open) task; (iii) investigated the matching of newcomers to available tasks in an ecosystem of OSS projects; (iv) investigated gender-specific newcomer barriers and strategies to increase diversity in OSS; and (v) developed a tool to analyze and label open issues from OSS projects. 


Our contributions are multifold. Our skills model provides a novel conceptual framework for newcomers and OSS communities to choose, analyze, label, and complete tasks. Our work has also identified the signals that potential newcomers look for when choosing tasks. A clear depiction of the skills needed for open tasks benefits newcomers to OSS projects who struggle to find a task to work with. We also provide a comprehensive view of how mentors, newcomers, and core contributors choose tasks in an OSS ecosystem and tooling to identify skills in OSS issues. We have developed tooling that automatically extracts the skills needed to complete a task and labels the issues (in the tracker) with the skills. Our empirical studies revealed that this kind of approach is feasible and relevant for OSS contributors and may inspire subsequent works for other types of skills and projects. Finally, we identified challenges and strategies to promote gender diversity and developed an automated tool to check for identifying inclusivity bugs in OSS projects. 


The impact of this project is more than just on research. We have released the software we developed as free, publicly available research prototypes. The project also directly trained 2 postdocs, 1 researcher, and 12 graduate, 18 undergraduate, and 4 high-school students on research. Many of these trainees are now faculty, have graduated and are now continuing with a doctoral study, or have secured jobs in the industry as software engineers. 


The ideas from this research will continue to impact products, projects, and our workforce for years to come, helping to improve the sustainability of OSS projects.
